May 23, 1901.

COLLEGE LIFE AT SEVILLE.
( Notes of a sometime student at Academio de Sevilla.)

HE Spanish student would stare at our
Tidea
of college life, for he does not feel the
American athletic enthusiasm. He is intent
on his cards and his beloved cigarettes, his
little games of strength, his evenings at
the theatre, with its rollicking "rough
house," or at the cafe, drinking much, but
seldom too much; he serenades, he makes love
at barred windows, he avenges with knife-andcloak duels offenses against his strict code of
etiquette. Life is jovial and care-free, but by
no means lawless, among these young subjects
of King Alfonso XIII.
However studious, however poor he may be,
the- Spanish student always finds time in the
evening to drop in at the café or the theatre.
This is but natural in a country where the
café takes the place of home-life for the male
members of the family after the late dinner.
At the little tables—of which there may be
four hundred or more in the great building,
open to the street—sit young and old, drinking, smoking, chaffing, watching the crowd.
This café-existence is all-important in the student's life; yet it cannot be reckoned dissipation, since a single order ensures a seat for the
whole evening, and even the most impecunious can afford to drink the red wine almost
like water. Fifteen cents will buy a bottle of
fairly good vintage, containing about one and
one-half pints. As in all wine-drinking countries of Europe, there is little intoxication in
Spain.
At the theatre, too, the student feels thoroughly at home. Everybody in the college
goes, two or three times a week. To this

No. 16

amusement also a scanty purse is no bar. The
Teatro ',or kora offers a succession of light
comedies, operas, etc., every hour, with a
slight intermission; and for each performance,
a good seat "down in front" costs but ten
cents. The orchestra, or pit is, in Spain, the
cheapest place in the theatre; the expensive
seats are the elevated stalls at the sides and
back. This is a survival of the original
"courtyard" theatre, where the common people poured into an enclosed courtyard to find
the stage at one end, and the nobility and people of consequence in the balconies surrounding the court. In the present Spanish theatre,
the balconies are low-priced towards the top,
and are much cultivated by the students. The
plays given are like our "curtain-raisers," domestic farces or light operas. There is a great
deal of dancing; the house always becomes attention at the click of the castanets, announcing the Sevillana with its supple, swaying,
graceful body-movements, so different from the
French hopping and skipping.
The students' highest jinks are on Innocents' Day and at the Carnival on Shrove
Tuesday. In the afternoon he sallies forth,
masked,and armed with bags of fiafielillos, bits
of paper cut so fine that it will bunch up
into a ball that can be thrown some distance,
but will burst at touch. He makes for the
Paseo, or public drive, where there is a grand
dress parade of everyone who can hire a carriage. Ah! a pretty face flashes by, and away
our student flies, jumps on the carriage steps,
and dashes, full in the girl's face, a bunch of
fiafielillos mingled with much gold tinsel. The
girl smiles at him—the more tinsel the greater
the compliment—and, hanging on the steps,
he enjoys a flirtation until someone slings

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

paftelillos down his neck, when he jumps off
and goes for his assailant. Perfect liberty is
peamitted, both from and towards any masker.
In the evening our student starts out for
the café, but has to run the gauntlet of the
balconies, where are girls with bags of flour
and weighted rag balls attached to strings, just
heavy enough to smash a stiff hat. When he
gets to the café, he finds it humming with the
revelers. The fun grows furious; he thoughtlessly runs across the open floor of the café in
his disguise, and thereby invites upon himself
a. shower of bread-crusts and rotten potatoes,
for such is the custom.
Then he joins a merry throng in the gallery
of the theatre. The rates are reduced tonight
so the building is crowded, and there is a flow
of jocular comments on the performance.
Meanwhile the esludiante in the gallery is
making some diablillos—"little devils." He
tears up his play-bill into narrow strips and
rolls these spirally into slender darts about
six inches long, with one end pointed and the
other flat. This wide end he presses between
the tips of his forefingers, and, drawing them
up and back, with a sharp jerk he shoots the
"little devil" into the lap of a pretty girl in a
box below. She does not notice, for sometimes there are as many as a hundred in the
air at once. But he continues his bombardment, and at last he is rewarded by a little
sweep and flutter of the fan, the Spanish woman's telegraph of feelings. In a moment
the duenna turns aside, and the marksman is
made blissful by a swift glance and smile.
But there is that "pig" who, they say, is engaged to her! and now a "malicious devil,"
with a pin stuck in the tip, zips down and
stings the rival's arm.
In such ways begin the love affairs of the
estudiante. He is very fond of the ladies, but
he has a hard time to meet them. In the first
place, no respectable Spanish girl is allowed to
call on friends, or to receive visitors, without
the presence and sanction of her mother or
other elderly relative. The express invitation
of the mother alone allows a young man to
call, even though he is engaged to the girl.
So the Spanish student's afaire du coeur

requires a deal of time and thought. If he
sees her first on the promenade, he must
shadow her, so persistently that she will notice
him, and yet so unobtrusively that the duenna
will not. Again a stolen look over the shoulder, with a signal of the eloquent fan, tells
that the young lady is conscious of his existence, and he traces her to her home. Then
he must, in student slang, hacer el oso,"play
the bear"—walk up and down, in front of the
house, at a certain hour each day. Meanwhile, he makes inquiries about the girl, and
tries to get word to her through mutual acquaintances; and, if fortunate, some day he
may see a handkerchief flutter behind the
window-bars. That night, muffled in his cafia,
or long mantle, he steals to the window, and
whispers his important communi cations
through the iron bars. For every window at
all accessible is provided with a stout iron
grating, an inheritance from the Moors, who
wished thus to insure the seclusion of their
ladies. The suitor may here propose for the
young lady's hand; but, unless he is accepted,
he may never reach a greater intimacy. So it
comes that a pedestrian through the streets of
Seville, by night, sees iii his walk twenty such
shrouded figures leaning against the gratings,
their cloaks pulled high over the head by the
left arm. If a student, he will say: "Another
fellow eating iron!''
The Spanish students are all great smokers;
fifteen to twenty cigarettes daily is an average
allowance. Cigars are costly, and pipes are
unknown. As with all the courteous Spaniard's conduct, the students have a most formal code of etiquette for smoking. Somebody
produces a tobacco-pouch. No matter where
he is, in a public conveyance or among strangers, he will offer the tobacco to all present.
Those who accept usually have their own pet
brand of papers, and so the cigarettes are
quickly rolled. Then the first man, as convivador, or host, lights his own cigarette. But it
would be a gross insult to offer a match for a
"light," so he hands his weed, the lighted end
foremost, to the nearest man, who returns it,
moistened end foremost,and forthwith passes his
own cigarette,now lighted,to his next neighbor.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
These rules must be scrupulously observed.
To throw away a cigarette which has been
returned from lighting is a deadly affront, and
calls for a duel.
These student duels, of frequent occurrence,
are fought with the navaja, or clasp-knife.
The ever-present cafia is rolled around the left
arm as a shield, and the wounds are apt to be
in the left hand. The scene is generally a
students' room. There is no stabbing, the
knife is slashed only; and cuts for the face are
not allowed. Since the fight may be stopped
at the option of the combatant who receives the
first wound, the duels are almost never fatal.
Intercollegiate athletics are unknown in
Spain. Fencing, hand-ball, and such games as
leap-frog, however, are popular, among them
the "bull-fight." The"bull" puts his hands
on his knees, and may use only his shoulders.
The " Torero" tries with his bands alone to
overthrow the "bull." Elbow-wrestling is
also a favorite amusement at the cafés. A
student, seated at a table with some stranger,
will enter into a test of strength with him.
The right arms are bent, the elbows leaned
side by side on the table, and the hands
clasped. He who, without moving his elbow,
can force his opponent's hand back upon the
table, enjoys a treat at the other's expense.
When he is at a "blow-out" with friends,
the student must also be careful of the proper
form. In quantities of over a quart, wine is
usually in leather bottles or skins, with a slender tube in the neck for a mouth-piece. There
are no glasses; so each man, as the bottle comes
around, leans far back in his chair, assures
himself that the mouth-piece is accurately
situated at a short distance from his mouth,
and then elevates the skin, causing the stream
to pour down his throat. On no account must
his lips touch the mouth-piece. If he can,
moreover, depress his epiglottis, so that no
action of gulping is necessary for the descent
of the •wine, he is considered quite accomplished.
It must not be thought that the estudiantes
are not good scholars. Indeed, many of them
at Seville were working their way through, in
various capacities ranging from a valet up-

3

wards. No record is kept of absences from
class, and no questions are asked—the professor does not even know his students' names,
But there is a "repetition'' held after each
lecture by a "quiz-master," by which the
subject is thoroughly reviewed. The examinations are every three months, and at the finals
are very severe, so that any trifling meets with
a speedy end.
The Spanish students are reckless youth,
with their fun and frolic and moonlight guitars.
Yet they are seldom too wild; and everywhere
and at all times, they have the traditional
courtesy that makes the Spaniard the most
dignified man of all nations.

MEDICAL SCHOOL ITEMS.
Commencement of the Nurse's TrainTHE
ing School connected with the Johns Hopkins Hospital will be held on Friday afternoon,
May 24th, in one of the hospital buildings.
The graduating class numbers eighteen.
sir W

Mr. Ed. H. Hume, Yale '97, of Bombay,
India, who has been following the medical
course at Hopkins for the past four years, has
been elected International Student to Great
Britian. On his graduation here, Mr. Hume
will leave for Liverpool, where he will pursue
his studies further.

HOPKINS
We extend sympathy and regret to Lafayette College, which has recently lost one of its
ablest professors—Dr. Thomas Conrad Porter,
Dean of the Pardee Scientific Department.
Asir W

last the efforts of"Mac" are rewarded,
ATand
Hopkins will have a gallery added to
the cage. In connection with this latest improvement, it would perhaps be well to direct
the attention of some of those profound critics
whose superior wisdom qualifies them to correct the mistakes (?) made by our Physical
Director, to a few of the innovations and improvements made by him during his incumbency of office.
When Mr. Mackdermott accepted the position as head of the athletic department of the
Johns Hopkins he found athletics in a lamentable condition. Since then he has remodeled
the entire athletic system of the University;
improved and lighted with electricity the cage,
secured suitable athletic grounds, and last but
not least, coached winning teams. It would
be well if certain of his detractors would pause
to consider a few of these things. However,

we are willing to be enlightened, and perhaps
some of these sage critics can suggest a better
man for the position. Now is your chance,
gentlemen, speak up! but remember, we need
a man who can do something besides put on a
lovely pair of tights and do"stunts" on the
horizontal bar. Up to this time the NEwsLETTER has refrained from entering this
controversy, but when the vital interests of
Hopkins athletics are involved it is time something should be said in the matter. Under
the present regime Hopkins athletics are
more flourishing than ever before, and their
welfare should not be sacrificed for the gratification of a few critics whose knowledge of
athletics is very limited, and whose contributions to the same have been mainly of the
"hot-air" variety.
Apropos to this we publish a letter from the
President of the Athletic Association regarding a certain poem published in the "Hullabaloo." In the effort to display wit (?) the
writer of the poem not only sacrificed truth,
but showed himself wofully incompetent to
write upon a subject which he evidently knows
nothing about. THP; NEws LETTER hopes
that these puerile attempts to injure the best
interests of Hopkins will be abandoned, and
that in the future all our men may have one
aim—namely, the honor and welfare of the
Black and Blue.

Editor of News-Letter.
Although the i9oi Hullabaloo is an excellent
production, it contains several articles that
should never have been allowed to appear.
It is one thing to ridicule, in a good natured
way, the peculiarities of a member of the faculty, and quite another thing to endeavor to
ruin his reputation by making all sorts of insinuations as to his habits and character.
The author of the poem "Drink Deep" has
not only done the present Director of Athletics a great injustice, but has shown very clearly that he, the author, does not know what he
is talking about. I have no desire to belittle

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the work done by our former instructor, because he and I were, and are still, the best of
friends, but the author of the poein should
have been very sure that he could firove that
our present instructor has ever used "unfair
means" to make our teams win. I do not
know who the author of this poem is, but I
venture the prediction that he is one of the
"side line" athletes who never played on a
team in his life, but who was always very liberal with his criticism of those who worked.
Again—can it be possible that the editors of
the Hullabaloo still believe that Mr. Mackdermott had anything to do with the handicapping that caused so much bad feeling after our
games at the armory? Yet, if they do not believe this, why did they permit the insinuation
that is so evident in the illustration of the
"Professor's Library" ? Why do not the gentlemen who write such articles and who have
been so busy circulating the slanderous reports
about the University and about town, come
out boldly and make definite charges against
the Director of Physical Training, that he may
be able to defend himself, and stop all this miserable squabbling that has been going on ever
since the football trouble last fall.
It is quite evident what the object of these
gentlemen is, and I would like to ask them
this one question—suppose you succeed, by
the persistent circulation of your rumors of
"crooked" work (none of which you have
been able to prove), in causing Mr. Mackdermott to resign;—what then? Have you a successor of equal, or anywhere near equal ability,
selected who will take his place, at the very
small salary which we can afford to pay? I
have asked this question a number of times
and have not yet received an answer.
To realize what Mr. Mackdermott has done
for Hopkins Athletics it is only necessary to
read the present Hullabaloo and one of six or
eight years ago. As to "crooked" work, I
could mention various examples in that line
that occurred long before Mr. Mackdermott
had anything to do with our athletics.
It is doubtless true that some of those who
have been circulating these rumors, really be-

5

lieve them to be true, but they do not seem to
realize that they are seriously injuring our
athletic reputation, as well as the reputation
of the Director of Athletics, by this method
of procedure.
If the author of "Drink Deep" really has
the interest of Hopkins Athletics at heart, let
him make formal charges, in writing, against
the Athletic Director, and lay these charges,
through Dr. Renouf, before the board for investigation.
In the meantime,—no more of these unproved rumors against the man who has done
so much to place Hopkins in the place she now
holds in the athletic world.
ALBERT M. Rimsn,
President Athletic Association.

A SPLENDID OPPORTUNITY.
seems indeed a blessing that once a year
IT the
students of the various Universities
are given an opportunity to assemble under
the cool pines of East Northfield, Conn., and
talk over common interests and discuss the
events of the day.
Here there is no chance for class politics
or fraternity factions creating disagreeable
cliques. No feeling can exist but that of true
'Christian friendship. It is hoped that this
year more Hopkins men will make use of the
opportunity thus offered to know one another
better, and to mingle with the students of
other Universities.
The date of opening is Friday, June 28th,
and of closing, Sunday night, July 7th, 1901.
From present indications, it is sure that the
attendance of the Conference, as a whole, will
be larger and more representative than ever.
A word as to what the Convention really is,
from a Hopkins man who was there, may be
of value.
Last year the total number of fellows at
Northfield was six hundred. Yale and Princeton had the largest delegations, Yale having

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

over one hundred men, and Princeton just
about one hundred. But, altogether, there
were men present from one hundred and fiftytwo different Colleges and institutions of learning. The men represented twenty-four different Christian denominations, though some
of them did not belong to any.
At the Conference, as much of the morning
as each man chose could be used in attending
different meetings, of which there were four,
each lasting but one hour, and beginning at
8 A. M.
The long afternoons were then given up to
recreation. Yale, Harvard, Amherst, Princeton, Williams, Brown, and several other Colleges, played for the baseball championship.
Some splendid tennis playing was also done
on the twelve courts, where the tennis tournament came very near being won by a Johns
Hopkins man. The fellows that didn't care
for baseball or tennis, were either playing
golf, climbing mountains, or rowing on the
waters of the historic Connecticut.
In the evening, about sunset, there was
always a meeting held on "Little Round
Top," where different life-works were presented to the men for consideration. Then,
at 8 o'clock, came the regular evening platform address, after which everyone started for
the camp. Now,some of the men lived in the
Northfield Seminary buildings near the large
Auditorium, but the majority dwelt in tents
on the mountain side, in a tall forest of tall
Cathedral pines, whose fallen needles have
been many years in spreading a thick carpet
round about our tents. The tents are erected
on'small board platforms, scattered amongst
the trees, within hearing distance of the big
gong on the rustic "hash-house,"to which place
there is a general stampede at 7 A. M.,
P. M., and 6 P. M. The camp is about half
a mile from the Auditorium, and is delightful,
both in equipment and situation.
Among the many pleasant memories of the
Conference last Summer, there is only space
to mention the gigantic bonfire on the evening
of July 4th, and the tremendous enthusiasm
of the Patriotic Celebration, on that same
evening, when, into the large Auditorium

marched the many delegations, each singing
their own College song, and then each delegation, composed of five or more men, sang to
the others a verse or so of its College song.
The Hopkins should have at least twenty-five
men this year to sing "'Rah for the Black
and Blue !" and give a good old Hullabaloo.
Pigeons were flying about the building with
Princeton flags attached. The Canadian Colleges were shouting,"Rule Britania." The
enthusiasm beggars all attempts at description.
It is, indeed, well worth your while to go
to Northfield, if only for the above reasons.
But there are still others. These pleasures
were enjoyed by the writer, they may be enjoyed by you ; but, like all others of their
kind, in a few weeks they have gone, and you
have only their memory. But, at Northfield
you can get more than this. Rev. Campbell
Morgan, of London, Mr. Robert E. Speer, of
New York, and President Seth Low, of
Columbia University, will speak ; and they
are men who know how to speak to men.
But, of more value even than the talks, perhaps, is the life—the very essence of life, with
which you feel yourself surrounded. You are
filled with a splendid optimism. You feel you
are beginning to see things in a new light, in
a true light; and that is the goal of us all.
You see about you, men who are true to themselves and to others, and you feel that you
yourself can become the same.
Information as to expenses, etc., may be
obtained from H. F. Perkins, or from A. R.
Bird, who will be only too glad to answer any
eiuestions, and give information to those who
believe they may be able to go there.
W

UNIVERSITY NEWS NOTES.
J. M. Vincent, Acting Director of the
DR.Historical
Department, is back at the
University, after an illness of several days.

President Gilman has been notified of his
re-election as vice-president of the Archaeological Institute of America.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
Dr. Herbert B. Adams is about to leave Baltimore for Amherst, Mass., where he will
spend a week before going to Nova Scotia for
the summer.
w w sr
President Gilman delivered an address at
Girard College on the 22d. He will also be
the Commencement Day Orator at the Woman's College.
sr w
The Phi Beta Kappa Initiation of the members elected at the recent meeting was held
Friday of last week, at 5 o'clock, in the Donovan Room.
WWW

James Wriner Harry, graduate in the Historical Department, has just been appointed
Fellow in History for the next year. He succeeds Wm. E. Martin, who will take his doctor's degree. Mr. Harry is an A. B. of
Georgetown College, Kentucky, 1899.
sr w sr
An invitation has been received from the
Imperial College of Agriculture, at Sapporo,
Japan, for their twenty-fifth anniversary,
which was held May 14th. Two graduates of
the University are now members of the Sapporo Faculty; Dr. Sato, the acting director,
and the professor of historical science.
W W W

Gen. Lloyd L. Jackson delivered an address
to the Senior Class, on Tuesday of last week.
Subject: "The choice of a business career for
college men." Gen. Jackson laid especial
emphasis on the growing need, in business
pursuits, of men of good education and integrity.
w sr sr
Thursday of last week the University was
visited by a party of nine gentlemen from
Cuba, and one from Porto Rico, who have
been attending the National Conference of
Charities in Washington. These visitors are
inspecting the methods of education and charitable work in this country, and were invited
by President Gilman to come to Baltimore.
Lieut.-Col. McHardy, of Edinburgh, Scotland,
was also present.

7

A novel course inAmerican history and diplomacy has been arranged for the graduate students in the Historical Department. An excursion will be made every Saturday to the
Capitol at Washington, where Dr. J. M.
Callahan, Albert Shaw lecturer on diplomatic history, will explain the important
documents in the State Department and Congressional Library.
WWW

Marathon M. Ramsey, a graduate student
in Romance Languages, has been appointed
Professor of Spanish in Leland-Stanford University. Mr. Ramsey is a graduate of Columbian University, where he obtained his A. M.
in 1895. He was for some time in the Secret
Service of the U. S. A., and was associated
with Lieutenant Rowan, who made the famous
trip across Cuba. Mr. Ramsey has written
several books on the Spanish language; his last
one is now used as a text-book in the public
schools of Cuba.

LACROSSE.
season of 1901 has been one
THEofLacrosse
the most successful we have seen,
though it did not land us another championship. This year we endeavored to play the
very best teams in the country, having little
idea that we could be so successful as we have
been. It being our stated policy to vie with
superiors, andl ose or win, as the case may be,
with honor, rather, than to win with ease from
weaker teams.
It is true we started our season this year
with the most sanguine hopes. Last year we
lost three of the best Lacrosse men we ever
had; MacInnes, whose place at in home we
hardly expected could be filled, Baetjer, whose
goal-protecting ability was unequaled, and
Foster, whose strong third defense field play
was unexcelled.. Then, too, "Billy" Maddren
could not be with us to inspire, encourage and
strengthen us. Knowing these difficulties, and
apparently having no one at hand to fill these
vacancies, and a free-for-all open season in
prospect, could we expect any more than
to play our best and lose? Contrary to our expectations we have had even a more glorious
season than heretofore.
Our first game opened as usual with the
"All Baltimores" who under the captaincy of
Maddren fully expected to win. But by steady,
careful playing of our new team, J. H. U. won
by a score six to one.
•
In this game it could be seen that even
though our men were small they were capable
of putting up a fair game of Lacrosse. Again
on April r3th, the Lacrosse Team from the
University of Pennsylvania visited us, and at
American League Park, in a hard, well contested game, we landed another victory for the
Black and Blue.
The Team of Teams, the Champions of the
the Country, The Crescents, we played next.
With the feeling of almost certain defeat, but
not with the usual nervousness, our Lacrosse
twelve appeared on Crescents' field in a pouring rain.
To the surprise of all, our magnificent team
work won, thus making us the first College

:77

team that has beaten the Crescents for twelve
years. It was, according to the Crescents, the
best exhibition of scientific Lacrosse that they
have seen, and they fully complimented our
boys. It is a fact, and unprecedented, that
there was not a miss-pass nor a miss-catch on
Hopkins' side during the whole game.
With our hopes now raised, we entered the
contest with City College of New York, at
Electric Park, and the fourth successive victory was won for the Black and Blue. Score
seven to one.
On May the fourth, with Columbia, we had
one of our hardest games, though comparatively easy victory. J. H. U. were victors by
a score of seven to one. On the following
Monday, the sixth, before we had recovered
from the Columbia game, we were on the field
against our supposed hardest proposition; Harvard. But by good, clean, clever work another victory was insured for Hopkins, score
four to naught. But this came not without
very adverse results. The boys who were cut
up somewhat in the Columbia game were made
worse by the severe checking of Harvard, and
a few of us were knocked out, causing no vain
hopes at Swarthmore. Not being able to practice for the following Saturday's game at
Swarthmore, our team endeavored to rest and
get in shape, but at Swarthmore it was evident
that this was not accomplished. In one of the
hardest fought games of Lacrosse J. H. U.
has witnessed, the Black and Blue lost the very
first game in four years to a college, Swarthmore. It was a hard fought game in every
sense, and the superior physical condition of
Swarthmore showed up in beautiful form, giving them the game four to two.
Thus the season for 1901 ended, with six
victories and one defeat, making one of the
best records in Hopkins Lacrosse.

'CELLO AND L
I went to call the other night
And, as she wished, I took my 'cello;
Her mother liked to hear me play,
So in the room she had to stay;
I played till ten, then came away—
Nothing doing.
I then bethought me of a plan
How, when I went the week ensuing.
There might, perchance,—Oh! Crafty man—
Be something doing.
I went again, this time supplied
With a trusty penknife by my side.
Then just as I began to play,
She chanced to turn her head away,
I cut my string—
Snap! "That's too bad,
It was the only A I had."
And so that night I couldn't play,
And mother didn't care to stay—
Plenty doing!
Howard J. White, in "The Bruonian."

May 23, 1901.

COLLEGE LIFE AT SEVILLE.
( Notes of a sometime student at Academio de Sevilla.)

HE Spanish student would stare at our
Tidea
of college life, for he does not feel the
American athletic enthusiasm. He is intent
on his cards and his beloved cigarettes, his
little games of strength, his evenings at
the theatre, with its rollicking "rough
house," or at the cafe, drinking much, but
seldom too much; he serenades, he makes love
at barred windows, he avenges with knife-andcloak duels offenses against his strict code of
etiquette. Life is jovial and care-free, but by
no means lawless, among these young subjects
of King Alfonso XIII.
However studious, however poor he may be,
the- Spanish student always finds time in the
evening to drop in at the café or the theatre.
This is but natural in a country where the
café takes the place of home-life for the male
members of the family after the late dinner.
At the little tables—of which there may be
four hundred or more in the great building,
open to the street—sit young and old, drinking, smoking, chaffing, watching the crowd.
This café-existence is all-important in the student's life; yet it cannot be reckoned dissipation, since a single order ensures a seat for the
whole evening, and even the most impecunious can afford to drink the red wine almost
like water. Fifteen cents will buy a bottle of
fairly good vintage, containing about one and
one-half pints. As in all wine-drinking countries of Europe, there is little intoxication in
Spain.
At the theatre, too, the student feels thoroughly at home. Everybody in the college
goes, two or three times a week. To this

No. 16

amusement also a scanty purse is no bar. The
Teatro ',or kora offers a succession of light
comedies, operas, etc., every hour, with a
slight intermission; and for each performance,
a good seat "down in front" costs but ten
cents. The orchestra, or pit is, in Spain, the
cheapest place in the theatre; the expensive
seats are the elevated stalls at the sides and
back. This is a survival of the original
"courtyard" theatre, where the common people poured into an enclosed courtyard to find
the stage at one end, and the nobility and people of consequence in the balconies surrounding the court. In the present Spanish theatre,
the balconies are low-priced towards the top,
and are much cultivated by the students. The
plays given are like our "curtain-raisers," domestic farces or light operas. There is a great
deal of dancing; the house always becomes attention at the click of the castanets, announcing the Sevillana with its supple, swaying,
graceful body-movements, so different from the
French hopping and skipping.
The students' highest jinks are on Innocents' Day and at the Carnival on Shrove
Tuesday. In the afternoon he sallies forth,
masked,and armed with bags of fiafielillos, bits
of paper cut so fine that it will bunch up
into a ball that can be thrown some distance,
but will burst at touch. He makes for the
Paseo, or public drive, where there is a grand
dress parade of everyone who can hire a carriage. Ah! a pretty face flashes by, and away
our student flies, jumps on the carriage steps,
and dashes, full in the girl's face, a bunch of
fiafielillos mingled with much gold tinsel. The
girl smiles at him—the more tinsel the greater
the compliment—and, hanging on the steps,
he enjoys a flirtation until someone slings

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

paftelillos down his neck, when he jumps off
and goes for his assailant. Perfect liberty is
peamitted, both from and towards any masker.
In the evening our student starts out for
the café, but has to run the gauntlet of the
balconies, where are girls with bags of flour
and weighted rag balls attached to strings, just
heavy enough to smash a stiff hat. When he
gets to the café, he finds it humming with the
revelers. The fun grows furious; he thoughtlessly runs across the open floor of the café in
his disguise, and thereby invites upon himself
a. shower of bread-crusts and rotten potatoes,
for such is the custom.
Then he joins a merry throng in the gallery
of the theatre. The rates are reduced tonight
so the building is crowded, and there is a flow
of jocular comments on the performance.
Meanwhile the esludiante in the gallery is
making some diablillos—"little devils." He
tears up his play-bill into narrow strips and
rolls these spirally into slender darts about
six inches long, with one end pointed and the
other flat. This wide end he presses between
the tips of his forefingers, and, drawing them
up and back, with a sharp jerk he shoots the
"little devil" into the lap of a pretty girl in a
box below. She does not notice, for sometimes there are as many as a hundred in the
air at once. But he continues his bombardment, and at last he is rewarded by a little
sweep and flutter of the fan, the Spanish woman's telegraph of feelings. In a moment
the duenna turns aside, and the marksman is
made blissful by a swift glance and smile.
But there is that "pig" who, they say, is engaged to her! and now a "malicious devil,"
with a pin stuck in the tip, zips down and
stings the rival's arm.
In such ways begin the love affairs of the
estudiante. He is very fond of the ladies, but
he has a hard time to meet them. In the first
place, no respectable Spanish girl is allowed to
call on friends, or to receive visitors, without
the presence and sanction of her mother or
other elderly relative. The express invitation
of the mother alone allows a young man to
call, even though he is engaged to the girl.
So the Spanish student's afaire du coeur

requires a deal of time and thought. If he
sees her first on the promenade, he must
shadow her, so persistently that she will notice
him, and yet so unobtrusively that the duenna
will not. Again a stolen look over the shoulder, with a signal of the eloquent fan, tells
that the young lady is conscious of his existence, and he traces her to her home. Then
he must, in student slang, hacer el oso,"play
the bear"—walk up and down, in front of the
house, at a certain hour each day. Meanwhile, he makes inquiries about the girl, and
tries to get word to her through mutual acquaintances; and, if fortunate, some day he
may see a handkerchief flutter behind the
window-bars. That night, muffled in his cafia,
or long mantle, he steals to the window, and
whispers his important communi cations
through the iron bars. For every window at
all accessible is provided with a stout iron
grating, an inheritance from the Moors, who
wished thus to insure the seclusion of their
ladies. The suitor may here propose for the
young lady's hand; but, unless he is accepted,
he may never reach a greater intimacy. So it
comes that a pedestrian through the streets of
Seville, by night, sees iii his walk twenty such
shrouded figures leaning against the gratings,
their cloaks pulled high over the head by the
left arm. If a student, he will say: "Another
fellow eating iron!''
The Spanish students are all great smokers;
fifteen to twenty cigarettes daily is an average
allowance. Cigars are costly, and pipes are
unknown. As with all the courteous Spaniard's conduct, the students have a most formal code of etiquette for smoking. Somebody
produces a tobacco-pouch. No matter where
he is, in a public conveyance or among strangers, he will offer the tobacco to all present.
Those who accept usually have their own pet
brand of papers, and so the cigarettes are
quickly rolled. Then the first man, as convivador, or host, lights his own cigarette. But it
would be a gross insult to offer a match for a
"light," so he hands his weed, the lighted end
foremost, to the nearest man, who returns it,
moistened end foremost,and forthwith passes his
own cigarette,now lighted,to his next neighbor.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
These rules must be scrupulously observed.
To throw away a cigarette which has been
returned from lighting is a deadly affront, and
calls for a duel.
These student duels, of frequent occurrence,
are fought with the navaja, or clasp-knife.
The ever-present cafia is rolled around the left
arm as a shield, and the wounds are apt to be
in the left hand. The scene is generally a
students' room. There is no stabbing, the
knife is slashed only; and cuts for the face are
not allowed. Since the fight may be stopped
at the option of the combatant who receives the
first wound, the duels are almost never fatal.
Intercollegiate athletics are unknown in
Spain. Fencing, hand-ball, and such games as
leap-frog, however, are popular, among them
the "bull-fight." The"bull" puts his hands
on his knees, and may use only his shoulders.
The " Torero" tries with his bands alone to
overthrow the "bull." Elbow-wrestling is
also a favorite amusement at the cafés. A
student, seated at a table with some stranger,
will enter into a test of strength with him.
The right arms are bent, the elbows leaned
side by side on the table, and the hands
clasped. He who, without moving his elbow,
can force his opponent's hand back upon the
table, enjoys a treat at the other's expense.
When he is at a "blow-out" with friends,
the student must also be careful of the proper
form. In quantities of over a quart, wine is
usually in leather bottles or skins, with a slender tube in the neck for a mouth-piece. There
are no glasses; so each man, as the bottle comes
around, leans far back in his chair, assures
himself that the mouth-piece is accurately
situated at a short distance from his mouth,
and then elevates the skin, causing the stream
to pour down his throat. On no account must
his lips touch the mouth-piece. If he can,
moreover, depress his epiglottis, so that no
action of gulping is necessary for the descent
of the •wine, he is considered quite accomplished.
It must not be thought that the estudiantes
are not good scholars. Indeed, many of them
at Seville were working their way through, in
various capacities ranging from a valet up-

3

wards. No record is kept of absences from
class, and no questions are asked—the professor does not even know his students' names,
But there is a "repetition'' held after each
lecture by a "quiz-master," by which the
subject is thoroughly reviewed. The examinations are every three months, and at the finals
are very severe, so that any trifling meets with
a speedy end.
The Spanish students are reckless youth,
with their fun and frolic and moonlight guitars.
Yet they are seldom too wild; and everywhere
and at all times, they have the traditional
courtesy that makes the Spaniard the most
dignified man of all nations.

HOPKINS
We extend sympathy and regret to Lafayette College, which has recently lost one of its
ablest professors—Dr. Thomas Conrad Porter,
Dean of the Pardee Scientific Department.
Asir W

last the efforts of"Mac" are rewarded,
ATand
Hopkins will have a gallery added to
the cage. In connection with this latest improvement, it would perhaps be well to direct
the attention of some of those profound critics
whose superior wisdom qualifies them to correct the mistakes (?) made by our Physical
Director, to a few of the innovations and improvements made by him during his incumbency of office.
When Mr. Mackdermott accepted the position as head of the athletic department of the
Johns Hopkins he found athletics in a lamentable condition. Since then he has remodeled
the entire athletic system of the University;
improved and lighted with electricity the cage,
secured suitable athletic grounds, and last but
not least, coached winning teams. It would
be well if certain of his detractors would pause
to consider a few of these things. However,

we are willing to be enlightened, and perhaps
some of these sage critics can suggest a better
man for the position. Now is your chance,
gentlemen, speak up! but remember, we need
a man who can do something besides put on a
lovely pair of tights and do"stunts" on the
horizontal bar. Up to this time the NEwsLETTER has refrained from entering this
controversy, but when the vital interests of
Hopkins athletics are involved it is time something should be said in the matter. Under
the present regime Hopkins athletics are
more flourishing than ever before, and their
welfare should not be sacrificed for the gratification of a few critics whose knowledge of
athletics is very limited, and whose contributions to the same have been mainly of the
"hot-air" variety.
Apropos to this we publish a letter from the
President of the Athletic Association regarding a certain poem published in the "Hullabaloo." In the effort to display wit (?) the
writer of the poem not only sacrificed truth,
but showed himself wofully incompetent to
write upon a subject which he evidently knows
nothing about. THP; NEws LETTER hopes
that these puerile attempts to injure the best
interests of Hopkins will be abandoned, and
that in the future all our men may have one
aim—namely, the honor and welfare of the
Black and Blue.

Editor of News-Letter.
Although the i9oi Hullabaloo is an excellent
production, it contains several articles that
should never have been allowed to appear.
It is one thing to ridicule, in a good natured
way, the peculiarities of a member of the faculty, and quite another thing to endeavor to
ruin his reputation by making all sorts of insinuations as to his habits and character.
The author of the poem "Drink Deep" has
not only done the present Director of Athletics a great injustice, but has shown very clearly that he, the author, does not know what he
is talking about. I have no desire to belittle

THE NEWS-LETTER.
the work done by our former instructor, because he and I were, and are still, the best of
friends, but the author of the poein should
have been very sure that he could firove that
our present instructor has ever used "unfair
means" to make our teams win. I do not
know who the author of this poem is, but I
venture the prediction that he is one of the
"side line" athletes who never played on a
team in his life, but who was always very liberal with his criticism of those who worked.
Again—can it be possible that the editors of
the Hullabaloo still believe that Mr. Mackdermott had anything to do with the handicapping that caused so much bad feeling after our
games at the armory? Yet, if they do not believe this, why did they permit the insinuation
that is so evident in the illustration of the
"Professor's Library" ? Why do not the gentlemen who write such articles and who have
been so busy circulating the slanderous reports
about the University and about town, come
out boldly and make definite charges against
the Director of Physical Training, that he may
be able to defend himself, and stop all this miserable squabbling that has been going on ever
since the football trouble last fall.
It is quite evident what the object of these
gentlemen is, and I would like to ask them
this one question—suppose you succeed, by
the persistent circulation of your rumors of
"crooked" work (none of which you have
been able to prove), in causing Mr. Mackdermott to resign;—what then? Have you a successor of equal, or anywhere near equal ability,
selected who will take his place, at the very
small salary which we can afford to pay? I
have asked this question a number of times
and have not yet received an answer.
To realize what Mr. Mackdermott has done
for Hopkins Athletics it is only necessary to
read the present Hullabaloo and one of six or
eight years ago. As to "crooked" work, I
could mention various examples in that line
that occurred long before Mr. Mackdermott
had anything to do with our athletics.
It is doubtless true that some of those who
have been circulating these rumors, really be-

5

lieve them to be true, but they do not seem to
realize that they are seriously injuring our
athletic reputation, as well as the reputation
of the Director of Athletics, by this method
of procedure.
If the author of "Drink Deep" really has
the interest of Hopkins Athletics at heart, let
him make formal charges, in writing, against
the Athletic Director, and lay these charges,
through Dr. Renouf, before the board for investigation.
In the meantime,—no more of these unproved rumors against the man who has done
so much to place Hopkins in the place she now
holds in the athletic world.
ALBERT M. Rimsn,
President Athletic Association.

A SPLENDID OPPORTUNITY.
seems indeed a blessing that once a year
IT the
students of the various Universities
are given an opportunity to assemble under
the cool pines of East Northfield, Conn., and
talk over common interests and discuss the
events of the day.
Here there is no chance for class politics
or fraternity factions creating disagreeable
cliques. No feeling can exist but that of true
'Christian friendship. It is hoped that this
year more Hopkins men will make use of the
opportunity thus offered to know one another
better, and to mingle with the students of
other Universities.
The date of opening is Friday, June 28th,
and of closing, Sunday night, July 7th, 1901.
From present indications, it is sure that the
attendance of the Conference, as a whole, will
be larger and more representative than ever.
A word as to what the Convention really is,
from a Hopkins man who was there, may be
of value.
Last year the total number of fellows at
Northfield was six hundred. Yale and Princeton had the largest delegations, Yale having

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

over one hundred men, and Princeton just
about one hundred. But, altogether, there
were men present from one hundred and fiftytwo different Colleges and institutions of learning. The men represented twenty-four different Christian denominations, though some
of them did not belong to any.
At the Conference, as much of the morning
as each man chose could be used in attending
different meetings, of which there were four,
each lasting but one hour, and beginning at
8 A. M.
The long afternoons were then given up to
recreation. Yale, Harvard, Amherst, Princeton, Williams, Brown, and several other Colleges, played for the baseball championship.
Some splendid tennis playing was also done
on the twelve courts, where the tennis tournament came very near being won by a Johns
Hopkins man. The fellows that didn't care
for baseball or tennis, were either playing
golf, climbing mountains, or rowing on the
waters of the historic Connecticut.
In the evening, about sunset, there was
always a meeting held on "Little Round
Top," where different life-works were presented to the men for consideration. Then,
at 8 o'clock, came the regular evening platform address, after which everyone started for
the camp. Now,some of the men lived in the
Northfield Seminary buildings near the large
Auditorium, but the majority dwelt in tents
on the mountain side, in a tall forest of tall
Cathedral pines, whose fallen needles have
been many years in spreading a thick carpet
round about our tents. The tents are erected
on'small board platforms, scattered amongst
the trees, within hearing distance of the big
gong on the rustic "hash-house,"to which place
there is a general stampede at 7 A. M.,
P. M., and 6 P. M. The camp is about half
a mile from the Auditorium, and is delightful,
both in equipment and situation.
Among the many pleasant memories of the
Conference last Summer, there is only space
to mention the gigantic bonfire on the evening
of July 4th, and the tremendous enthusiasm
of the Patriotic Celebration, on that same
evening, when, into the large Auditorium

marched the many delegations, each singing
their own College song, and then each delegation, composed of five or more men, sang to
the others a verse or so of its College song.
The Hopkins should have at least twenty-five
men this year to sing "'Rah for the Black
and Blue !" and give a good old Hullabaloo.
Pigeons were flying about the building with
Princeton flags attached. The Canadian Colleges were shouting,"Rule Britania." The
enthusiasm beggars all attempts at description.
It is, indeed, well worth your while to go
to Northfield, if only for the above reasons.
But there are still others. These pleasures
were enjoyed by the writer, they may be enjoyed by you ; but, like all others of their
kind, in a few weeks they have gone, and you
have only their memory. But, at Northfield
you can get more than this. Rev. Campbell
Morgan, of London, Mr. Robert E. Speer, of
New York, and President Seth Low, of
Columbia University, will speak ; and they
are men who know how to speak to men.
But, of more value even than the talks, perhaps, is the life—the very essence of life, with
which you feel yourself surrounded. You are
filled with a splendid optimism. You feel you
are beginning to see things in a new light, in
a true light; and that is the goal of us all.
You see about you, men who are true to themselves and to others, and you feel that you
yourself can become the same.
Information as to expenses, etc., may be
obtained from H. F. Perkins, or from A. R.
Bird, who will be only too glad to answer any
eiuestions, and give information to those who
believe they may be able to go there.

A novel course inAmerican history and diplomacy has been arranged for the graduate students in the Historical Department. An excursion will be made every Saturday to the
Capitol at Washington, where Dr. J. M.

Marathon M. Ramsey, a graduate student
in Romance Languages, has been appointed
Professor of Spanish in Leland-Stanford University. Mr. Ramsey is a graduate of Columbian University, where he obtained his A. M.
in 1895. He was for some time in the Secret
Service of the U. S. A., and was associated
with Lieutenant Rowan, who made the famous
trip across Cuba. Mr. Ramsey has written
several books on the Spanish language; his last
one is now used as a text-book in the public
schools of Cuba.

LACROSSE.
season of 1901 has been one
THEofLacrosse
the most successful we have seen,
though it did not land us another championship. This year we endeavored to play the
very best teams in the country, having little
idea that we could be so successful as we have
been. It being our stated policy to vie with
superiors, andl ose or win, as the case may be,
with honor, rather, than to win with ease from
weaker teams.
It is true we started our season this year
with the most sanguine hopes. Last year we
lost three of the best Lacrosse men we ever
had; MacInnes, whose place at in home we
hardly expected could be filled, Baetjer, whose
goal-protecting ability was unequaled, and
Foster, whose strong third defense field play
was unexcelled.. Then, too, "Billy" Maddren
could not be with us to inspire, encourage and
strengthen us. Knowing these difficulties, and
apparently having no one at hand to fill these
vacancies, and a free-for-all open season in
prospect, could we expect any more than
to play our best and lose? Contrary to our expectations we have had even a more glorious
season than heretofore.
Our first game opened as usual with the
"All Baltimores" who under the captaincy of
Maddren fully expected to win. But by steady,
careful playing of our new team, J. H. U. won
by a score six to one.
•
In this game it could be seen that even
though our men were small they were capable
of putting up a fair game of Lacrosse. Again
on April r3th, the Lacrosse Team from the
University of Pennsylvania visited us, and at
American League Park, in a hard, well contested game, we landed another victory for the
Black and Blue.
The Team of Teams, the Champions of the
the Country, The Crescents, we played next.
With the feeling of almost certain defeat, but
not with the usual nervousness, our Lacrosse
twelve appeared on Crescents' field in a pouring rain.
To the surprise of all, our magnificent team
work won, thus making us the first College

:77

team that has beaten the Crescents for twelve
years. It was, according to the Crescents, the
best exhibition of scientific Lacrosse that they
have seen, and they fully complimented our
boys. It is a fact, and unprecedented, that
there was not a miss-pass nor a miss-catch on
Hopkins' side during the whole game.
With our hopes now raised, we entered the
contest with City College of New York, at
Electric Park, and the fourth successive victory was won for the Black and Blue. Score
seven to one.
On May the fourth, with Columbia, we had
one of our hardest games, though comparatively easy victory. J. H. U. were victors by
a score of seven to one. On the following
Monday, the sixth, before we had recovered
from the Columbia game, we were on the field
against our supposed hardest proposition; Harvard. But by good, clean, clever work another victory was insured for Hopkins, score
four to naught. But this came not without
very adverse results. The boys who were cut
up somewhat in the Columbia game were made
worse by the severe checking of Harvard, and
a few of us were knocked out, causing no vain
hopes at Swarthmore. Not being able to practice for the following Saturday's game at
Swarthmore, our team endeavored to rest and
get in shape, but at Swarthmore it was evident
that this was not accomplished. In one of the
hardest fought games of Lacrosse J. H. U.
has witnessed, the Black and Blue lost the very
first game in four years to a college, Swarthmore. It was a hard fought game in every
sense, and the superior physical condition of
Swarthmore showed up in beautiful form, giving them the game four to two.
Thus the season for 1901 ended, with six
victories and one defeat, making one of the
best records in Hopkins Lacrosse.

'CELLO AND L
I went to call the other night
And, as she wished, I took my 'cello;
Her mother liked to hear me play,
So in the room she had to stay;
I played till ten, then came away—
Nothing doing.
I then bethought me of a plan
How, when I went the week ensuing.
There might, perchance,—Oh! Crafty man—
Be something doing.
I went again, this time supplied
With a trusty penknife by my side.
Then just as I began to play,
She chanced to turn her head away,
I cut my string—
Snap! "That's too bad,
It was the only A I had."
And so that night I couldn't play,
And mother didn't care to stay—
Plenty doing!
Howard J. White, in "The Bruonian."
